summary: The appellant-University has been granted permission by the All India Council for the Technical Education to start a department for a course or programme in technical education or a technical institution as an adjunct to the University itself to conduct technical courses of its choice and selection. The All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) has made it clear that it will not approve the admissions made by any University to any courses or programmes without prior approval from it. The appellant has urged the Supreme Court to hold that the provisions of the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) Act, Rules and Regulations framed by the AICTE are not binding or enforceable against the appellant by the mere fact that they were framed in pursuance of the said Act.

summary: The Revenue has filed appeals against the decisions of a Division Bench of the High Court of Kerala on a reference application at the instance of the assessees under Section 256(1) of the Income Tax Act, 1961. In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court of India has held that capital gains tax could not be levied upon the assessees in respect of the sale by them of their shares in the amalgamated company because there was no provision in the Income Tax Act with regard to the manner of determination of the cost of these shares.

summary: A very sad tale concerning fourteen young kids resulting in untimely and unfortunate death of all of them stands out to be the subject matter of the Appeal under consideration: Sad tale reason of the fact that a sheer fun of young ones turned out to be fatal as a consequence of utter and callous neglect of teachers on duty. On 28th May, 1995, 14 students of Dalhousie Public School, Badhani drowned in Dibber river in Kangra district of Punjab. In the light of the report of the CBI, it has been contended that the High Court should not award compensation to the parents on the basis of emotion and sentiments.

summary: The appellants are Jasbir Rani and Ors, both residents of Jalandhar, Punjab. The Punjab and Haryana High Court has dismissed two writ petitions challenging the fixed cut-off date in two separate advertisements issued by the State Government for the posts of constables. The Court has held that the cut-off date by reference to which the eligibility requirement must be satisfied by the candidate seeking a public employment is the date appointed by the relevant service rules and if there be no cut-off date appointed by the rules then such date as may be appointed for the purpose in the advertisement calling for applications.

summary: Appeal by Ashok Yeshwant Badave against an order passed by the Bombay High Court dismissing writ application filed by the appellant upholding an order passed by a Sessions Court in refusing to interfere with the order passed by a Chief Judicial Magistrate taking cognizance and issuing process against the appellant for the offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881. Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Laws (Amendment) Act, 1988 (Act 66 of 1988) makes it an offence for a drawer of negotiable instruments to draw a cheque without sufficient funds in his account maintained by him in a bank and induces the payee or holder in due course. The concept of post-dated cheque has been well known even in common law and it was in effect a bill of exchange payable on demand with a post date upon which the demand was to be made.

The High Court committed a serious error in holding that the execution petition filed earlier by the appellants was not maintainable as the decree passed by the High Court merged in the decree passed by this Court when the appeal was dismissed and that the appellants had to file a fresh application for execution subject to law of limitation; the High Court was also not right in saying that the question of title could be decided afresh in the event of fresh execution petition being filed as stated above.

summary: The Calcutta High Court has granted special leave to two senior clerks of the Indian Railways to appeal against a tribunal's decision not to grant them promotion on the ground of seniority. This appeal is against the decision of the Central Administrative Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, quashing the seniority list published on 2.11.89, and the private respondents having been declared senior to the present appellants, on the basis of the date of regular promotion, after due process of selection. The counsel for the Railway Administration, appearing for the respondents, on the other hand, urged the Supreme Court to overturn the decision of the tribunal, which had held that the ad hoc period for reckoning seniority in the cadre of Senior Clerk, was not counted for the purpose of seniority.

summary: Appeal (civil) 7112-7113 of 2001 PETITIONER: State of Punjab Vs. The Punjab and Haryana High Court has held that a notification issued by the State of Punjab prescribing reservation of 40% in postgraduate medical courses at the Postgraduate Medical Education and Training University, Jalandhar, in violation of the Medical Council of India Regulations. The High Court of Madhya Pradesh has struck down as ultra vires the prescription of 40% marks at the entrance test for admission to postgraduate medical courses as against 50% marks at the entrance test prescribed by the Medical Council of India for all students in the proviso to Regulation 9(2).

summary: Appeal by the State of Uttar Pradesh against the judgement of the Allahabad High Court which held that Kurk Amins appointed on commission basis by different District Magistrates/Collectors within the State of Uttar Pradesh for realisation of outstanding dues of the various cooperative societies as arrears of land revenue can be treated to be employees of the State Government holding civil post under the State of Uttar Pradesh within the meaning of Article 311 of the Constitution of India as they are entitled to a scale. Two appeals were preferred before this Court by the State of Uttar Pradesh against the High Court's decision of 16.11.1985 which held that Kurk Amins appointed on commission basis were not entitled to regular scale as was payable to Kurk Amins of Revenue Department. A Division Bench of the Supreme Court, comprising Justices GSSinghvi and VS Sirpurkar, is hearing an appeal filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh against the decision of the Allahabad High Court that Kurk Amins appointed on salary basis for realisation of dues of co-operative societies, held civil posts and became Government servant.

summary: The facts in this criminal appeal disclose acts of unparalleled evil and barbarity as five persons of a family were battered to death without mercy by a young culprit aged about 20 years. Appellant Shri Bhagwan Soni was a resident of Sardar Shahar in Sujangarh district of Rajasthan. The counsel for the appellant has raised serious doubts on the evidence adduced by the prosecution as it is proved that the appellant was seen with one of the deceased Jora Ram in the evening of 14th November, 1993 and the appellant had an acquaintance with the family members of the deceased as he had already worked as an apprentice in the shop of PW-17 to learn the trade of goldsmithy.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a suit simpliciter for specific performance of contract for sale of immovable property is a "suit for land" within clause 12 of Letters Patent of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay. It is clear that the High Court in exercise of its ordinary original jurisdiction will have power to receive, try and determine suits of every description, if such property is situated within the local limits of original jurisdiction of the High Court. The Bombay High Court in a recent case considered the import of the expression "suit for land".

summary: This case has been listed for hearing in the Supreme Court on 9 May, 2001. summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a student of medical college in New Mumbai can migrate to a medical college in his home town on certain medical grounds. Regulation 6(5) of the Indian Medical Council of India regulates the migration of students from one University to another University for the purpose of appearing for the IInd professional Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBBS) examination at the transferee college. The Supreme Court of India has dismissed the appeal of the Medical Council of India against the High Court's order that the council should be dissolved.

summary: The judgments and orders of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, Lucknow Bench, in Writ Petition No.7548(S/S) of 1996 are available at: In his appeal against the order of the High Court directing payment of full wages to workman pending proceedings in higher courts, the petitioner has contended that Section 17-B of the Industrial Disputes (Amendment) Act, 1982, which provides for payment of full wages to workman pending proceedings in higher courts, is not sustainable. summary: The Court of Appeal for the State of West Bengal has set aside the judgment of the Calcutta High Court setting aside the order passed by the Authorised Officer under the Indian Forest Act (as amended in the State of West Bengal), confiscating certain tools and implements. The learned single judge of the High Court of West Bengal has held that the confiscation of a saw mill and its machinery by the Authorised Officer of the State of West Bengal was wholly illegal. The Supreme Court of India has set aside a High Court ruling which had ordered confiscation of a Band Saw and other implements allegedly used in illicit felling and removal of timber from a forest area in West Bengal.

summary: The High Court of Tamil Nadu has quashed the proceedings initiated against two of the accused in a criminal complaint alleging commission of offences punishable under Sections 193, 196, 197, 406, 465, 468 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code. The High Court of Delhi has quashed the criminal proceedings against the respondents in a civil case. The Supreme Court in a landmark case has held that a criminal proceedings can be quashed only where the allegations made in the complaint or the first information report are so absurd and inherently improper that on the basis of which no prudent person could have reached a just conclusion that there were sufficient grounds in proceeding against the accused or where there is an express legal bar engrafted in any provisions of the Code or any other statute to the institution and continuance of the criminal proceedings or where a criminal proceeding is manifestly actuated with malafide and has been initiated maliciously with the ulterior motive of wrecking vengeance on the accused and with a view to spite him due to private and personal grudge.

summary: The Labour Court of Madhya Pradesh has dismissed the appeals of seven workmen who were sacked for conspiring to allow a sugarcane farmer to bring sugar cane to the Gwalior Sugar Company without bringing it to the mill. summary: The Calcutta High Court has ruled in favour of Dalmia Cement (Bharat) in a decade-long case. The Kerala High Court has held that a complaint against a person for non-payment of a cheque issued under the provisions of the Merchant Vessels' Act, 1956, can be filed within the statutory period from the date of receipt of the notice. The High Court has held that a complaint under Section 138 of the Prevention of Money laundering Act can be filed within 30 days from the date of alleged receipt of the first notice by the accused.

summary: Appeal (civil) 1505 of 1988 PETITIONER SHRI HAFAZAT HUSSAIN S/O MUBARAK HUSSAIN Vs. The plaintiffs in the present suit claimed to be Mutwallis of Waqf Mosque Rangileshah and also of the Wakf created by Hazi Mohammed Siddiq. The First Appellate Judge, after noticing the facts considered by the learned Trial Judge, has chosen to record that before considering any other issue in the suit as has been done by the learned Trial Judge, the first point for determination in the appeal should be as to whether Smt. summary: The High Court of Kerala has answered the following questions: The question before us is whether the Explanation to 271(1)(c) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961 is binding on the Income Tax Officer or the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in respect of cases in which the Income Tax Officer or the Appellate Assistant Commissioner is satisfied that a person has concealed the particulars of his income or furnished inaccurate particulars of such income. summary: Appeal by Special Leave, order passed by Sikkim High Court, in Criminal Leave Application dismissing the same after holding that no sanction under Section 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1974 is required for prosecution of the appellant. The appellant, who was Secretary, Department of Rural Development, Government of Sikkim at the time of commission of the alleged offence, a preliminary objection was raised before the Special Judge to the effect that his prosecution under Section 120-B of the Indian Penal Code read with Sections 5(2) and 5(1)(d) of the 1947 Act was not warranted as he being a public servant at the relevant time. Section 197 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) provides for the protection of public servants from prosecution for offences committed while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of their official duty.

summary: A chronology of key events: The Jharkhand High Court has held that the transfer of 36 criminal cases from the erstwhile State of Bihar to the State of Jharkhand as a sequel to the bifurcation of the erstwhile State of Bihar was permissible under the Jharkhand Reorganisation Act, 2000. In the case of the Animal Husbandry Scam, the Special Judge appointed under the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (PC) Act, 1993 could have exercised jurisdiction over the entire State of Bihar at a time when a court created earlier (as per notification of 19.4.1994) could have exercised jurisdiction in the two regions which fell within Jharkhand area.

summary: The appellant has challenged the judgment rendered by Patna High Court whereby revision application has been allowed, order passed by the Court, rejecting objection under Section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure (hereinafter referred to as the Code) to executing executability of decree passed in title suit No. 115 of 1977, set aside and objection allowed. The High Court of Bihar in a suit brought by a former management of a college against the Bihar University held that a decree passed against the erstwhile management of the college was null and void as it was not made party in the suit. It is plain that if the right to sue survives and no application for bringing legal representatives of a deceased party is filed within the time prescribed, there is automatic abatement of the suit and procedure has been prescribed for setting aside abatement under Rule 9 on the grounds postulated therein.

The appellant Vijay Kumar Sharma has produced on record Office Memorandum dated 17th August 1974 (Annexure P-6) written by the Deputy Secretary to the Engineer in Chief, Irrigation Department, U.P. on the subject of transfer of services of Assistant Engineers working in Community Development Department being allotted to Irrigation Department on the basis of competitive examination shall be treated as transferred from that department which inter alia provides that their services on joining in Irrigation Department shall be treated as transferred from that department and shall also be counted towards fixation in the same pay scale. The appellants were appointed as Assistant Engineers in the Public Works Department (PWD) on ad hoc basis in the year 1962.

summary: Appeal by Bhaskar Industries Ltd against the order of the Sessions Judge, overlooking a legal interdict, interfered with an interlocutory order and created a situation for the trial to remain nonplussed. The Supreme Court has set aside an order of the Bombay High Court which had set aside an order of the Sessions Court which had framed charges against two accused in the 1993 serial blasts case. In the present case, the appellants raised the issue of maintainability of the revision petition before the Court on the ground that the order passed by the trial court was "unmaintainable".

summary: On 24 January, 2001 the Supreme Court of India heard a series of petitions relating to the claim of refund of water cess paid by the respondents as water cess under the provisions of the Water (Prevention and Control of)U.P. summary: Appeal by the Union of India and Others against the judgment and order of the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad made in Special Application Nos. The Supreme Court is considering whether the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court at Ahmedabad should be established to adjudicate on the claim of Adani Exports Ltd. The Court of Appeal in Oswals case (supra) has held that the High Court at Ahmedabad does not have the territorial jurisdiction to hear a writ petition filed in respect of a consignment of beef tallow which has arrived at the Calcutta Port.

summary: A chronology of key judgements: Two appeals have been heard by the Supreme Court of India on the issue of jurisdiction of the Rent Controller under the Rent Control Act of Delhi when the said Act was amended in the year 1999 to exclude tenancies with respect to those tenancies fetching monthly rent exceeding Rs.31985. summary: Appeal (civil) 4172-73 of 1999 PETITIONER: G. Mallikarjunappa And Another vs Shamanur Shivashankarappa & Others on 4 April, 2001 Two election petitions were filed in the High Court of Karnataka against the election of G. Mallikarjunappa and others on the ground that the affidavit filed by appellant No.2 as an election agent of appellant No.1 was not in the format prescribed under Rul e 94-A of the Representation of the People Act. In the case of Dr Vijay Laxmi Sadho v. Jagdish, JT 2001(1) SC 382, this Court opined: "We are in respectful agreement with the view expressed in F.A. Sapa's case (supra) and in view of settled law the conclusion becomes irresistible that defect in verification of an affidavit is curable and does not merit dismissal of an election petition in limine under Section 86 (1) of the Act."

summary: Appeal by British Airways Plc against an order of the Delhi High Court which held that the appellants were not liable to pay penalty under the Customs Act, 1962 because they were not the 'persons incharge' of the aircraft. The Indian Customs Act, 1961 (the "Act"), provides for the collection of duties on goods imported into India and on goods transhipped under the provisions of the Act. The Supreme Court has held that a person representing the officer incharge to the officers of the customs as his agent for the purposes of dealing with the cargo off-loaded from the aircraft of the appellants carrier should be liable in terms of Section 2(31) of the Customs Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that the State is liable to pay interest on the sums involved in land acquisition proceedings under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894. The issue of interest on solatium in acquisition of land was first raised in the Supreme Court of India in Periyar & Pareekanni Rubbers Ltd 1991(4) SCC 195 where Learned Judges (L.M. Sharma, J, as he then was, and K. Ramaswamy, J) in the concluding part of that decision said as follows: "Therefore, we have no hesitation to hold that Section 25(3) contemplates payment of interests on solatium to re-compensate the owner of the land for loss of user of the land from the date of taking possession till date of payment into court. The appellants in this appeal contended that the solatium payable under Section 23 of the Land Acquisition Act is not part of the compensation.

summary: The Supreme Court has issued a set of guidelines to ensure that the exercise of discretion in making such allotments are in conformity with the rule of law and by excluding the likelihood of arbitrariness and minimising the area of discretion. Two writ petitions, challenging the validity of the allotment of petrol pumps/gas agencies to various persons during the period 1992-93, 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96 had been filed in this Court. In the case of about 400 allottees of petrol retail outlets, LPG distributorship and Kerosene distributorship, the Court disposed of the cases of about 100 allottees by its judgment dated 29th of August, 1997.

summary: The facts and events leading to filing of these Special Leave Petitions are as follows: A writ petition has been filed in the High Court challenging the order of the National Green Tribunal quashing the panel of selected candidates giving the reasons that number of vacancies originally notified were 330 but the panel of selected candidates had been drawn for 917 without earlier notifying the increase in vacancies; only 18 Physically Handicapped candidates had been selected instead of 27 candidates on the basis of 3% reservation for the entire 917 posts; instead of finding the selection zone, applications of SC/STs were received on inter-State basis and that the marking pattern in the selection in the absence of guidelines to 80% marks had led to wide variations. A Division Bench of the Delhi High Court, headed by Chief Justice Gita Mittal, passed an order quashing the recruitment notification issued by the Union of India to fill up 917 vacancies in Group D of the Indian Railways.

summary: The appellants who were appointed as Traffic Apprentices in Southern Railway prior to May 15, 1987, have filed this appeal challenging the judgment of the Madras Bench of the Central Administrative Tribunal (for short the CAT) dated October 4, 1996 in OA No. The Supreme Court of India in a landmark case has set aside the judgment of the Madras Bench of the Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) which had declared as invalid a memorandum issued by the Union of India which had revised the pay scale of Traffic Apprentices. The learned counsel appearing for the appellants contended that the directions in paragraphs 17 & 18 of the judgment in M. Bhakar's case (supra) by which they have been seriously prejudiced were not made without giving notice to the appellants and/or other similarly placed employees who were seriously prejudiced by such directions.

summary: This case has been listed for hearing by the Supreme Court of India on 25 April, 2001. The Judgment of the High Court held that the Appellant's second Application was barred on principles of constructive res-judicata. Section 44-A of the Code of Civil Procedure reads as follows : "44-A (1) Where a certified copy of a decree of any of the superior Courts of any reciprocating territory has been filed in a District Court, the decree may be executed in India as if it had been passed by the District Court."

summary: This is a group of appeals against the orders of the High Court of Maharashtra and the Supreme Court of India in the case of Maharashtra Health Sciences Common Entrance Test (MH-CET). A writ petition was filed in the High Court of Maharashtra challenging the decision of the State Government to deny admission to students who were already admitted on the basis of the first merit list. A Division Bench of the Supreme Court of India comprising Justices Dipak Misra and AMKhanwilkar has taken up the appeal of the Central Government and Medical Council of India against a verdict of the Bombay High Court.

summary: The Calcutta High Court has set aside an order of transfer of an officer in Middle Management Grade II of the State Bank of India. The Division Bench of Calcutta High Court by its order dated 10.2.92, directed the respondent to join his new posting at Siliguri within fifteen days. The Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court has totally lost sight of the fact that it was dealing with the legality of an order of transfer of an employee and not dealing with a criminal case, where the conviction had been maintained on the basis of a confessional statement.

summary: All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) is an autonomous premier institution of national importance. The Indian Institute of Medical Sciences (IIMS) was established under the provisions of the Indian Medical Council Act, 1933, with the aim of (a) to produce graduates and post-graduates of outstanding excellence in the fields of medical sciences and (b) to bring together educational facilities of the highest order for the training of personnel in all the important branches of health activity. summary: Appeal by the Union of India against the judgment of the Bombay High Court in the case of Elphinstone Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Ltd. The Union of India vs Elphinstone Spinning & Weaving Co. The writ petitions were filed by three Mills against the impugned Act and the High Court of India was of the opinion that the impugned Act was unconstitutional as it was clubbing the three Mills with other Mills in category three, enumerated in the Schedule appended to the Act and such inclusion violates the fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution.

summary: The issue that has come up for consideration and decision in this appeal is whether use of one room to attend some office files at home in a building leased for residential purpose, renders a tenant liable for his eviction from the building under Section 13(2)(iib) of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949. The appellant Atul Castings Ltd has moved the High Court against the eviction of the appellant Bawa Gurvachan Singh from the premises of Atul Castings Ltd on the ground that he has been using the building for his business and partly for his residence. The appellant has been using the demised premises for the purpose of residence only and for no other purpose.

summary: The Supreme Court of India is the highest court in the country. A writ petition was filed in the Delhi High Court by the owner of goods which were seized by the customs authorities on the basis of a licence issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports. On 10 April, 2001 the Delhi High Court in the writ petition of Jain Woolen Mills & Ors directed the carrier of the goods, including the appellant to release the goods without any conditions but such release will be subject to the ultimate decision in these appeals.

summary: The appellants are directly recruited Deputy Tehsildars and their service conditions are governed by Andhra Pradesh Revenue Subordinate Service Rules, 1961. The High Court of Andhra Pradesh has set aside the judgement of the Administrative Tribunal and the High Court and held that the seniority of the Deputy Tehsildars should be re-drawn up in accordance with the amended Rules on the basis of total length of service without reference to the date of confirmation and without reference to Rule 4(e). The learned counsel appearing for the Deputy Tehsildars has contended that the High Court in its judgement in the case in hand has committed serious error in holding that the seniority of Deputy Tehsildars in the cadre should be determined in accordance with Rule 4(e), as it existed prior to amendment of 1992.

summary: This case has been listed for hearing by the Supreme Court on 2 August, 2001. summary: Appeal by special leave is directed against an order of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dated 4th February, 2000 rejecting applications (I.A. 2806/99 and 5957/99) filed by the appellant, the returned candidate, seeking rejection of an electio petition filed by the respondent challenging his election on various grounds contained in those applications. petitioner had filed an affidavit in support of the allegations of corrupt practice verifying the facts stated in parag aphs 5 to 17 as based on his 'personal knowledge' and not on the basis of 'information received' from any other source. In Prabhu Narain vs A.K. Srivastava : (1975) 3 SCC 788, the Supreme Court had held that " Rule 2(b) of the Madhya Pradesh High Court Rules provides that every election petition shall be written in English language and since the election petition filed by the respondent was written in Hindi and not English language, the same was liable to be dismissed for non-compliance with the said rule, in limine."

summary: The appellant Adhyatma Bhattar Alwar and the respondent Adhyatma Bhattar Sri Devi were married on 22nd August, 1978 in Nalamvari Choultry at Rajahmundry. The Punjab and Haryana High Court has set aside the judgment and decree of the trial Court and dismissed the appeal filed by the husband, holding that the wife did not have at any time the necessary animus to put an end to the matrimonial relationship and never intended to desert her husband. If a spouse abandons the other spouse in a state of temporary passion, for example, anger or disgust, without intending permanently to cease cohabitation, it will not amount to desertion.
